articles.headline: Europe Seems to Agree on Recapitalizing Banks — but How?
articles.snippet: France wants to dip into the European bailout fund to replenish its banks’ capital stock; Germany says no. The dispute between two biggest guarantors of the fund clouds any end to the debt crisis.
articles.abstract: France wants to dip into the European bailout fund to replenish its banks’ capital stock; Germany says no. The dispute between two biggest guarantors of the fund clouds any end to the debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: European leaders are finally coming around to the view that banks must be compelled to replenish their capital reserves if the euro area is ever to emerge from the debt crisis. But whether the politicians can make it happen in a convincing manner is another question — especially given that Germany and France are already divided.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Slovaks Love and Hate Euro; Bailout May Lie in Between
articles.snippet: Bailouts for Greece and other European countries have touched a nerve in Slovakia, which is threatening to derail a rescue plan.
articles.abstract: Bailouts for Greece and other European countries have touched a nerve in Slovakia, which is threatening to derail a rescue plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — In a television advertisement for the popular Slovak beer Zlaty Bazant, a grinning man with a paunch stands on a sunny beach, nodding his head as the narrator says, “To want to borrow from everyone, that is Greek.” The ad then cuts to a skinny man, standing in a field, who shakes his head. “To not want to lend to anyone,” the narrator says, “that is Slovak.”

articles.headline: Checking Account Wars, Behind the Scenes
articles.snippet: As the battle is joined over fees, the big banks want to make you pay, and the most aggressive of the little institutions want to pay you.
articles.abstract: As the battle is joined over fees, the big banks want to make you pay, and the most aggressive of the little institutions want to pay you.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, Senator Dick Durbin took to the Senate floor and called for a run on Bank of America.

articles.headline: Where Post Office Is the Town’s Heart, Fears of Closings
articles.snippet: The deficit-plagued Postal Service has warned 3,700 communities, most rural, that it may shutter the post offices that many residents rely on to pick up their mail and keep up with area news.
articles.abstract: The deficit-plagued Postal Service has warned 3,700 communities, most rural, that it may shutter the post offices that many residents rely on to pick up their mail and keep up with area news.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEVILLE, Ohio — While checking for mail on her daily visit, Susan Reid regaled the town postmaster with news of the wonderful swimming lessons enjoyed by her two home-schooled children. Suddenly, her 9-year-old son began tumbling around, ever so playfully, on the floor, as if he were at home.

articles.headline: E-Mail Shows Senior Energy Official Pushed Solyndra Loan
articles.snippet: A senior Energy Department official inquired frequently about the progress of the loan even though his wife’s law firm represented the company and he promised to recuse himself.
articles.abstract: A senior Energy Department official inquired frequently about the progress of the loan even though his wife’s law firm represented the company and he promised to recuse himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior Energy Department official pushed hard for the government’s $535 million loan to the now-bankrupt California solar energy company Solyndra even after he had disclosed that his wife’s law firm represented the company and he had promised to recuse himself from matters related to the loan application, according to e-mails provided to Congressional investigators by the administration.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Scan-to-Buy Gets a Trial on Television
articles.snippet: In an experiment, the shopping network HSN will use data squares similar to bar codes on its high-definition channel, a code some retailers see as potentially lucrative.
articles.abstract: In an experiment, the shopping network HSN will use data squares similar to bar codes on its high-definition channel, a code some retailers see as potentially lucrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a television experiment, shoppers this weekend watching HSN, the shopping network, can scan their TV screens with a smartphone to learn more about the products on display, and, HSN hopes, become more inclined to buy them.

articles.headline: In G.O.P. Race, Foreign Policy Is a Footnote
articles.snippet: So far, the Republican presidential candidates have been prone to occasional blunders when delving into foreign policy — that is, when they have had anything to say about the topic at all.
articles.abstract: So far, the Republican presidential candidates have been prone to occasional blunders when delving into foreign policy — that is, when they have had anything to say about the topic at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Herman Cain suggested that Israel’s conservative prime minister would be open to allowing Palestinians right of return to the lands they fled in what is now Israel. Gov. Rick Perry suggested it was possible that American troops could be sent to Mexico if drug violence there got worse. And former Senator Rick Santorum offered that the United States should engage with the ousted Pakistani dictator Pervez Musharraf — now living in self-exile in London — to respond to the threat of Pakistan’s nuclear weapons falling into the wrong hands.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Grilled Chicken, That Temperamental Star
articles.snippet: Tabletop directors are commercial artists whose goal is to make mundane foods look so irresistible that people want to eat the TV.
articles.abstract: Tabletop directors are commercial artists whose goal is to make mundane foods look so irresistible that people want to eat the TV.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE sauce will not behave.

articles.headline: 17 Countries, but Even More Unknowns
articles.snippet: Despite assurances from the Treasury secretary and others, investors still know little about the risks of American banks’ exposure to Europe’s woes.
articles.abstract: Despite assurances from the Treasury secretary and others, investors still know little about the risks of American banks’ exposure to Europe’s woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: “THE direct exposure of the U.S. financial system to the countries under the most pressure in Europe is very modest.”

articles.headline: Poker Inc. to Uncle Sam: Shut Up and Deal
articles.snippet: Legalizing and regulating poker on the Internet could bring billions of dollars to government coffers, supporters say.
articles.abstract: Legalizing and regulating poker on the Internet could bring billions of dollars to government coffers, supporters say.
articles.lead_paragraph: JESUS FERGUSON and Howard Lederer (“the Professor”) did not invent online poker. They just took it to new heights — and, according to the authorities, new depths — as their company, Full Tilt Poker, became a gambling palace of the Web.

articles.headline: For Romney, Social Issues Pose New Test
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney is again being forced to explain his Mormon faith and his stance on social issues to his party’s base.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney is again being forced to explain his Mormon faith and his stance on social issues to his party’s base.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by  Michael D. Shear, Erik Eckholm and  Ashley Parker and written by Mr. Shear.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Erik Eckholm and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Inflating the Software Report Card
articles.snippet: Debate continues to rage over the effectiveness of technology in learning, and how best to measure it.
articles.abstract: Debate continues to rage over the effectiveness of technology in learning, and how best to measure it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Web site of Carnegie Learning, a company started by scientists at Carnegie Mellon University that sells classroom software, trumpets this promise: “Revolutionary Math Curricula. Revolutionary Results.”
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Clamping Down on Rapid Trades in Stock Market
articles.snippet: Regulators are weighing rules to rein in high-speed, computerized trading, and officials in the United States, Europe and Canada may impose fees aimed at limiting volume.
articles.abstract: Regulators are weighing rules to rein in high-speed, computerized trading, and officials in the United States, Europe and Canada may impose fees aimed at limiting volume.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators in the United States and overseas are cracking down on computerized high-speed trading that crowds today’s stock exchanges, worried that as it spreads around the globe it is making market swings worse.

articles.headline: Daughter of ‘Dirty War,’ Raised by Man Who Killed Her Parents
articles.snippet: A trial could finally prove that top military rulers in Argentina engaged in a systematic plan to steal babies from perceived enemies of the government.
articles.abstract: A trial could finally prove that top military rulers in Argentina engaged in a systematic plan to steal babies from perceived enemies of the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Victoria Montenegro recalls a childhood filled with chilling dinnertime discussions. Lt. Col. Hernán Tetzlaff, the head of the family, would recount military operations he had taken part in where “subversives” had been tortured or killed. The discussions often ended with his “slamming his gun on the table,” she said.

articles.headline: Secret U.S. Memo Made Legal Case to Kill a Citizen
articles.snippet: A memo offers a glimpse at the legal debate that led to the Obama administration’s decision to kill Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen, in Yemen.
articles.abstract: A memo offers a glimpse at the legal debate that led to the Obama administration’s decision to kill Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen, in Yemen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s secret legal memorandum that opened the door to the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born radical Muslim cleric hiding in Yemen, found that it would be lawful only if it were not feasible to take him alive, according to people who have read the document.

articles.headline: Germany and France Say Deal Near to Recapitalize Banks
articles.snippet: Leaders of the two countries promised more coordination of economic policies, but declined to provide specifics on how the bank recapitalization would work, or how much money they would commit.
articles.abstract: Leaders of the two countries promised more coordination of economic policies, but declined to provide specifics on how the bank recapitalization would work, or how much money they would commit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Acknowledging that Europe’s banks still need billions of euros to cushion against a possible default by Greece, the leaders of Germany and France announced on Sunday that they would have a package of reforms by the time leaders of the Group of 20 nations meet in early November.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Judy Dempsey

articles.headline: Church Protests in Cairo Turn Deadly
articles.snippet: In the worst violence since February, at least 24 people were killed Sunday when a protest by Christian Egyptians escalated into rioting against military rule.
articles.abstract: In the worst violence since February, at least 24 people were killed Sunday when a protest by Christian Egyptians escalated into rioting against military rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A demonstration by Christians angry about a recent attack on a church touched off a night of violent protests here against the military council now ruling Egypt, leaving 24 people dead and more than 200 wounded in the worst spasm of violence since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in February.

articles.headline: Free Texts Pose Threat to Carriers
articles.snippet: New ways to bypass charges for text messages could take a big bite out of wireless carriers’ profits.
articles.abstract: New ways to bypass charges for text messages could take a big bite out of wireless carriers’ profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when e-mail and many other forms of electronic communication are essentially free, wireless carriers are still charging as much as 20 cents to send a text message to a phone, and another 20 cents to receive it.

articles.headline: Banks Brace for Fallout on Earnings
articles.snippet: Banks, the fulcrum of a huge protest downtown, may be about to prove disheartened investors right.
articles.abstract: Banks, the fulcrum of a huge protest downtown, may be about to prove disheartened investors right.
articles.lead_paragraph: The protesters who have gathered for weeks near Wall Street and the highly paid investors and analysts in the buildings that surround them don’t agree on much.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Recession Officially Over, U.S. Incomes Kept Falling
articles.snippet: In a grim sign of the enduring nature of the economic slump, a new report shows that despite some improvement in the economy, household incomes have lagged.
articles.abstract: In a grim sign of the enduring nature of the economic slump, a new report shows that despite some improvement in the economy, household incomes have lagged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a grim sign of the enduring nature of the economic slump, household income declined more in the two years after the recession ended than it did during the recession itself, new research has found.

articles.headline: Labor Talks in Detroit Go Social
articles.snippet: Although contract negotiations still take place in private, Web sites and social media have provided faster, more accurate and more inclusive communication.
articles.abstract: Although contract negotiations still take place in private, Web sites and social media have provided faster, more accurate and more inclusive communication.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For generations, labor negotiations here have been the stuff of closed doors and tight lips. Just four years ago, when the United Auto Workers settled on contracts with the Big Three, the rank-and-file learned the details by crowding into union halls for meetings that were often chaotic and confusing. Many workers complained that they had not seen the fine print until the deals had been ratified.

articles.headline: A Protest’s Ink-Stained Fingers
articles.snippet: Even in an environment preoccupied with digital media, a newspaper has gained traction as a tool of protest at the Occupy Wall Street rallies.
articles.abstract: Even in an environment preoccupied with digital media, a newspaper has gained traction as a tool of protest at the Occupy Wall Street rallies.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Occupy Wall Street demonstration in Zuccotti Park, you’ll find all of the essentials of a state-of-the-art protest: drum circles, cheeky and plaintive handwritten signs, and, next to a thrumming generator, a hub of social media activity, including live streaming of the proceedings.

articles.headline: Victory Lap for Fox and Hannity
articles.snippet: The cable news channel, given little chance of succeeding in 1996, is celebrating its anniversary this month with a national tour.
articles.abstract: The cable news channel, given little chance of succeeding in 1996, is celebrating its anniversary this month with a national tour.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When the Fox News host Sean Hannity arrived at Centennial Olympic Park here on Thursday night, some of the hundreds of fans who had been waiting for him since sunset rushed to the rope line for handshakes and autographs. He obliged, then bounded onto a temporary stage two blocks from the CNN Center and asked them mischievously, “Do you think it’s any coincidence that the CNN logo is in the background?”

articles.headline: As Its Economy Sprints Ahead, China’s People Are Left Behind
articles.snippet: China’s current economic system favors state-run banks and companies over wage earners, who are largely denied the benefits of the nation’s remarkable growth.
articles.abstract: China’s current economic system favors state-run banks and companies over wage earners, who are largely denied the benefits of the nation’s remarkable growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: JILIN CITY, China — Wang Jianping and his wife, Shue, are a relatively affluent Chinese couple, with an annual household income of $16,000 — more than double the national average for urban families.

articles.headline: After Rocky Start, More Study, and Sleep, for Perry
articles.snippet: Aides to Gov. Rick Perry acknowledge that the transition to presidential candidate has been difficult.
articles.abstract: Aides to Gov. Rick Perry acknowledge that the transition to presidential candidate has been difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas struggled through his first three debates, so his aides have staged practice sessions, complete with a stand-in for Mitt Romney. He has stirred outrage among conservatives on immigration, so he is defending his stance on the campaign trail as good economics.

articles.headline: 2 American Professors Awarded Nobel in Economic Science
articles.snippet: Thomas J. Sargent and Christopher A. Sims, two Americans, won the Nobel economics prize on Monday “for their empirical research on cause and effect in the macroeconomy.”
articles.abstract: Thomas J. Sargent and Christopher A. Sims, two Americans, won the Nobel economics prize on Monday “for their empirical research on cause and effect in the macroeconomy.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nobel in economic science was awarded on Monday to Thomas J. Sargent of New York University and Christopher A. Sims of Princeton University for their research on the cause and effect of government policies on the broader economy, a major concern of countries still struggling to address the aftermath of the recent financial crisis.

articles.headline: U.N. Finds ‘Systematic’ Torture in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A United Nations report provides a devastating picture of abuses committed by arms of the Afghanistan government as foreign forces there are moving to wind down their presence.
articles.abstract: A United Nations report provides a devastating picture of abuses committed by arms of the Afghanistan government as foreign forces there are moving to wind down their presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Detainees are hung by their hands and beaten with cables, and in some cases their genitals are twisted until the prisoners lose consciousness at sites run by the Afghan intelligence service and the Afghan National Police, according to a United Nations report released here on Monday.
